title: The Adventure of the Beryl Coronet
text:
"The Adventure of the Beryl Coronet", one of the 56 short <a href="Sherlock%20Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a> stories written by Sir <a href="Arthur%20Conan%20Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a>, is the eleventh of the twelve stories collected in "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Sherlock%20Holmes">The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes</a>". The story was first published in "<a href="The%20Strand%20Magazine">The Strand Magazine</a>" in May 1892.
Plot.
A banker, Mr. Alexander Holder of <a href="Streatham">Streatham</a>, makes a loan of £50,000 (equivalent to approximately £ in ) to a socially prominent client, who leaves a <a href="beryl">beryl</a> <a href="coronet">coronet</a>—one of the most valuable public possessions in existence—as collateral. Holder feels that he must not leave this rare and precious piece of <a href="jewellery">jewellery</a> in his personal safe at the bank, and so he takes it home with him to lock it up there. He is awakened in the night by a noise, enters his dressing room, and is horrified to see his son Arthur with the <a href="coronet">coronet</a> in his hands, apparently trying to bend it. Holder's niece Mary comes at the sound of all the shouting and, seeing the damaged coronet, faints dead away. Three <a href="beryl">beryl</a>s are missing from it. In a panic, Mr. Holder travels to see Holmes, who agrees to take the case.
The case against Arthur seems rather damning, yet Holmes is not convinced of his guilt. Why is Arthur refusing to give a statement of any kind? How could Arthur have broken the coronet (even Holmes, who has exceptionally strong hands, can barely do it) and without making any noise? Could any other people in the household be involved, such as the servants, or Mary? Could some visitor, such as the maid's wooden-legged suitor, or Arthur's rakish friend Sir George Burnwell, have something to do with what happened to the coronet? The failure to resolve the case will result in Mr Holder's dishonour, and a national scandal.
Holmes sets about not only reviewing the details that he learns from Holder but also by examining the <a href="footprints">footprints</a> in the <a href="snow">snow</a> outside. Eventually, Holmes solves the mystery, and Holder is flabbergasted to find that his niece was in league with a notorious criminal (Sir George Burnwell), although apparently, she is unaware of his character. The two of them escape justice; however, Holmes is convinced that they will receive their punishment in due time. Arthur's motive in allowing his father to think he was the thief was that he was in love with his cousin Mary and saw her passing the coronet to Burnwell outside the window. (The coronet was broken when Arthur was struggling to wrench it from Burnwell's grasp.) Holmes regains the jewels after threatening Sir George at gunpoint with an offer of £1,000 apiece (for each of the 3 beryls); Burnwell is shocked at Holmes' offer—he had already sold them to a <a href="fence">fence</a> for £300. With the additional offer of no prosecution, Holmes buys the beryls from the fence for £3,000; Holmes receives £4,000 compensation but sternly scolds Holder that he owes his son an apology for erroneously assuming Arthur had stolen the coronet.
Publication history.
"The Adventure of the Beryl Coronet" was first published in the UK in "<a href="The%20Strand%20Magazine">The Strand Magazine</a>" in May 1892, and in the United States in the US edition of the "Strand" in June 1892. The story was published with nine illustrations by <a href="Sidney%20Paget">Sidney Paget</a> in "The Strand Magazine". It was included in the short story collection "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Sherlock%20Holmes">The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes</a>", which was published in October 1892.
Adaptations.
Film and television.
The 1912 short film "The Beryl Coronet" was released in the <a href="Sherlock%20Holmes%20%28%C3%89clair%20film%20series%29">Éclair film series</a> featuring <a href="Georges%20Tr%C3%A9ville">Georges Tréville</a> as Sherlock Holmes.
The story was dramatised as a 1921 silent short film as part of the <a href="Sherlock%20Holmes%20%28Stoll%20film%20series%29">Stoll film series</a> starring <a href="Eille%20Norwood">Eille Norwood</a> as Holmes.
The story was adapted for an episode of the 1965 television series "<a href="Sherlock%20Holmes%20%281965%20TV%20series%29">Sherlock Holmes</a>" with <a href="Douglas%20Wilmer">Douglas Wilmer</a> as Holmes, <a href="Nigel%20Stock%20%28actor%29">Nigel Stock</a> as Watson, <a href="Leonard%20Sachs">Leonard Sachs</a> as Holder and <a href="Suzan%20Farmer">Suzan Farmer</a> as Mary. It also featured <a href="David%20Burke%20%28British%20actor%29">David Burke</a> as Sir George Burnwell. Burke would later play Watson opposite <a href="Jeremy%20Brett">Jeremy Brett</a> in the first two seasons of "<a href="Sherlock%20Holmes%20%281984%20TV%20series%29">The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes</a>".
A 2001 episode of the animated television series "<a href="Sherlock%20Holmes%20in%20the%2022nd%20Century">Sherlock Holmes in the 22nd Century</a>", titled "The Adventure of the Beryl Board", was based on the story.
The story was used in part in the <a href="Elementary%20%28TV%20series%29">"Elementary"</a> episode 'How the Sausage Is Made.'
Radio.
<a href="Edith%20Meiser">Edith Meiser</a> adapted the story as an episode of the radio series "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Sherlock%20Holmes%20%28radio%20series%29">The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes</a>" which aired on 28 January 1932, with <a href="Richard%20Gordon%20%28actor%29">Richard Gordon</a> as Sherlock Holmes and Leigh Lovell as Dr Watson. Other episodes adapted from the story aired on 24 March 1935 (with <a href="Louis%20Hector">Louis Hector</a> as Holmes and Lovell as Watson) and 26 September 1936 (with Gordon as Holmes and Harry West as Watson).
A dramatisation of "The Beryl Coronet" was broadcast on the <a href="BBC%20Light%20Programme">BBC Light Programme</a> on 30 June 1959, as part of the <a href="Sherlock%20Holmes%20%281952%20radio%20series%29">1952–1969 radio series</a> starring <a href="Carleton%20Hobbs">Carleton Hobbs</a> as Holmes and <a href="Norman%20Shelley">Norman Shelley</a> as Watson. The cast also included <a href="Frederick%20Treves%20%28actor%29">Frederick Treves</a> as Arthur Holder and <a href="Ronald%20Baddiley">Ronald Baddiley</a> as Roberts. It was adapted by <a href="Michael%20Hardwick">Michael Hardwick</a>.
"The Adventure of the Beryl Coronet" was dramatised as a 1977 episode of the series "<a href="CBS%20Radio%20Mystery%20Theater">CBS Radio Mystery Theater</a>" with <a href="Kevin%20McCarthy%20%28actor%29">Kevin McCarthy</a> as Sherlock Holmes and Court Benson as Dr. Watson.
The story was adapted by Vincent McInerney for <a href="BBC%20Radio%204">BBC Radio 4</a> in 1991 as an episode of the <a href="Sherlock%20Holmes%20%281989%20radio%20series%29">1989–1998 radio series</a> starring <a href="Clive%20Merrison">Clive Merrison</a> as Holmes and <a href="Michael%20Williams%20%28actor%29">Michael Williams</a> as Watson. It featured <a href="Anthony%20Newlands">Anthony Newlands</a> as Holder, <a href="Angus%20Wright%20%28actor%29">Angus Wright</a> as Arthur, <a href="Petra%20Markham">Petra Markham</a> as Mary, and <a href="Timothy%20Carlton">Timothy Carlton</a> (father of <a href="Benedict%20Cumberbatch">Benedict Cumberbatch</a>, another famous Sherlock) as Sir George Burnwell.
A 2010 episode of the radio series "<a href="The%20Classic%20Adventures%20of%20Sherlock%20Holmes">The Classic Adventures of Sherlock Holmes</a>" was adapted from the story, with <a href="John%20Patrick%20Lowrie">John Patrick Lowrie</a> as Holmes and Lawrence Albert as Watson.
<a href="Radio%20Mirchi">Radio Mirchi</a>Bangla adapted this story for their <a href="Sunday%20Suspense">Sunday Suspense</a> series on 12 September 2021.
<a href="Mir">Mir</a> enacted as Sherlock Holmes and Deep enacted the role of Dr. Watson.
Print.
The novel "The Further Adventures of Sherlock Holmes": "The Improbable Prisoner" by Stuart Douglas is a subtle 'sequel' to this story.
